item.title: Normal Curve
item.description: (red curve is the normal curve) ~68% is within one standard deviation of the mean [[Normal Distribution]] The normal curve, also known as the bell curve or the Gaussian curve, is a symmetrical and continuous probability distribution that describes the variation of many natural phenomena.

item.title: Normal Distribution
item.description: ~68% fall under the normal [[Normal Curve]] describes how data is spread out around a central value. For example, if you measure the heights of many people, you will find that most of them are close to the average height, and only a few are much taller or shorter.

item.title: Ethical Considerations in Research
item.description: Ethical considerations are principles that guide research code of conduct Why? to protect rights of research participants enhance research validity

item.title: Literature Review
item.description: Definition a literature review surveys books, scholarly articles, and any other sources relevant to a particular issue, area of research, or theory, and by so doing, provides a description, summary, and critical evaluation of these works in relation to the research problem being investigated 1

item.title: Research Methodology Syllabus
item.description: Module 1: Introduction [[Introduction to Research Methodologies]] What is Research Characteristics Objectives Motivation Types of Research analytical, descriptive; applied, fundamental; quant, qual;

item.title: Research Problem and Sources
item.description: What is a research problem? A research problem is a question that the research hopes to answer specific issue or gap in existing knowledge

item.title: How To Write a Research Proposal
item.description: 1. Identification of problem State as a question ![[Steps in Formulating Research Problem]] 2. Review of Literature (remember that your problem is most definitely NOT NOVEL)

item.title: Research Methodology 2
item.description: Organize Treat Interpret Data Quantitative Qualititative T-Test Manipulation of sample and variables Types of Research Diagnostic Research - Frequency Hypothesis Testing - Experiment

item.title: Hypothesis
item.description: tentative answer/explanation to question/problem to the point, clear not vague Types of Hypotheses Alternative Null Complex Sample Statistical Empirical Null Hypothesis proposes no relationship between two variable

item.title: Introduction to Research Methodologies
item.description: What is Research? is a process of systematic inquiry that aims to increase the knowledge of a topic or issue

item.title: Methods of Research
item.description: Survey (Questionnaire???) Quantitative Interview Structured Unstructured Telephone Observation used in both quant and qual

item.title: Reliability
item.description: Reliability (of a tool) refers to consistency of the tool. The tool must give the same / similar results no matter how many tries / testing and retesting.

item.title: RM IV
item.description: Statistics - science - collecting, organizing, interpreting Norm - Average 50% population [[Averages#1. Mean|Mean]] - a type of average where the sum total is divided by the number of elements

item.title: Sample, Universe, Population
item.description: Sample, Universe, Population Sample A sub-section of the population a representation of the population inference is generalized Process of Sampling Define the population Develop [[Sampling Frame]] Select a Samling Method Determine sample size Execute the sampling process Sampling Population

item.title: Steps in Formulating Research Problem
item.description: Identify broad field -> Dissect the subareas -> selected interested sub-area -> raise research questions -> formulate objective -> Assess Objective -> Double Check

item.title: Types of Averages
item.description: Types of Averages - 1. Mean 2. Median 3. Mode

item.title: Types of Research
item.description: Quatitative Research Qualitative Research Descriptive Research Analytical research includes surveys, and fact-finding enquiries usually no manipulation; ex post facto occuring naturally/not in a lab
